awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Designing Learning Environments to Foster Productive and Powerful Discussions among Linguistically Diverse Students in Secondary Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will design and investigate learning environments in secondary mathematics classrooms focused on meeting the needs of English language learners. An ongoing challenge for mathematics teachers is promoting deep mathematics learning among linguistically diverse groups of students while taking into consideration how students' language background influences their classroom experiences and the mathematical understandings they develop. In response to this challenge, this project will design and develop specialized instructional materials and guidelines  for teaching fundamental topics in secondary algebra in linguistically diverse classrooms. The materials will incorporate insights from current research on student learning in mathematics as well as insights from research on the role of language in students' mathematical thinking and learning. A significant contribution of the work will be connecting research on mathematics learning generally with research on the mathematics learning of English language learners. In addition to advancing theoretical understandings, the research will also contribute practical resources and guidance for mathematics teachers who teach English language learners. The Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program is a National Science Foundation (NSF)-wide activity that offers awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education, and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations.

The project is focused on the design of specialized hypothetical learning trajectories that incorporate considerations for linguistically diverse students. One goal for the specialized trajectories is to foster productive and powerful mathematics discussions about linear and exponential rates in linguistically diverse classrooms. The specialized learning trajectories will include both mathematical and language development learning goals. While this project focuses on concepts related to reasoning with linear and exponential functions, the resulting framework should inform the design of specialized hypothetical learning trajectories in other topic areas. Additionally, the project will add to the field?s  understanding of how linguistically diverse students develop mathematical understandings of a key conceptual domain. The project uses a design-based research framework gathering classroom-based data, assessment data, and interviews with teachers and students to design and refine the learning trajectories. Consistent with a design-based approach, the project results will include development of theory about linguistically diverse students' mathematics learning and development of guidance and resources for secondary mathematics teachers. This research involves sustained collaboration with secondary mathematics teachers and the impacts will include developing capacity of teachers locally, and propagating the results of this work in professional development activities.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on redesigning high school mathematics classroom learning environments to foster productive and powerful discussions in classes with a linguistically diverse group of students. From prior research we know that classroom discussions can be a powerful lever for promoting student learning in school mathematics, but many multilingual students who are learning the language of schooling have limited access to classrooms where mathematical concepts are learned in and through discussions.


Across the life of the project, the PI worked with seven collaborating high school teachers, six graduate student researchers, and ten undergraduate research assistants to develop project-specific design principles for promoting productive and powerful discussions in linguistically diverse secondary classrooms. The research team engaged in two cycles of design research across four years. Each cycle included collecting data from classrooms and from student interviews; analyzing the data to understand students' social, cultural, and linguistic resources and challenges related to the mathematical focus; developing curriculum units that built on students' resources; and then teaching the newly developed units in the context of everyday instruction. The design efforts focused on curriculum units that addressed the mathematical topic of reasoning about linear and exponential rates of change as a paradigmatic case.


Through engaging in two cycles of design research, the team articulated three project-specific design principles: 


DP1: Align a conceptual focus and problem contexts across the unit to minimize linguistic complexity;


DP2: Integrate mathematical-language goals linked to the conceptual focus; and 


DP3: Incorporate strategic language support in daily lesson activities. 


Intellectual Merit: The project-specific design principles synthesize prior research that has focused on developing students' mathematical understandings and research that focuses on fostering discussions in mathematics classrooms. This project lays the foundation for future development of classroom learning environments in which multilingual students can develop robust understandings of key mathematical ideas through participating in classroom discussions. The scholarly products have been disseminated in five peer-reviewed scholarly journal articles, six conference proceedings, four non peer-reviewed articles and book chapters, and six scholarly conference presentations. Additional publications are under review or in development.


Broader Impact: The project directly contributed to broader impacts through the development of a diverse group of student researchers and future mathematics education or STEM professionals. Additionally, the practical products of this research have been shared in dozens of professional development sessions with teachers from all parts of the country. These products are disseminated on the project website and are continuing to evolve as the PI and former graduate student mentees conduct professional development with these materials. Some of the professional development sessions are one-time workshops while others are series of professional development sessions. To date, hundreds of teachers have participated in professional development sessions that are based on the design principles developed during this project. This professional development work is ongoing and will continue past the life of this project.
